description: Introduction to Svelte, the compiler-based framework. Learn how it differs from React/Vue.

slides.title: What is Svelte?
slides.content:
# The Compiler üè≠

Svelte is NOT a library you ship to the browser (like React/Vue).

It is a **Compiler** that runs at build time.

It converts your components into highly efficient vanilla JavaScript that surgically updates the DOM.

slides.title: No Virtual DOM
slides.content:
# No Virtual DOM üö´

React/Vue use a Virtual DOM to diff changes.

Svelte doesn't need it. Because it compiles your code, it knows exactly *where* variables are used and generates code to update *only* those text nodes when variables change.

slides.title: Component Structure
slides.content:
# Structure üß± A `.svelte` file has 3 parts (just like HTML): ```html

Hello {name}!

```

slides.title: Reactive Declarations
Logic Blocks
Loops
slides.content:
# Each Loop üìã Iterate over lists. ```html
    {#each items as item (item.id)}
  • {item.name}
    • {/each}
``` The `(item.id)` part is the key.

slides.title: Events
slides.content:
# Event Listening üëÇ Use the `on:` directive. ```html
The mouse is at {m.x} x {m.y}
``` Modifiers: `on:click|preventDefault={handler}`.

slides.title: Bindings
slides.content:
# Two-Way Binding üéÄ

```html
<input bind:value={name}>
```

When input changes, `name` updates.
When `name` changes, input updates.

Works on media elements too: `<video bind:currentTime={time} />`.

slides.title: Code Example
Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Svelte Basics üéì

Less boilerplate.

- **Compiler:** No Virtual DOM.
- **Reactivity:** Just assign variables (`count += 1`).
- **Derived:** `$: doubled = count * 2`.
- **Logic:** `{#if}`, `{#each}`.
- **Events:** `on:click`.
